description.narrative: This Grant will help the National Disease Programs to reduce by 60% the morbidity and mortality of malaria; TB mortality by 35% and HIV prevalence rate to less than 3%.

participating-org.narrative: GLOBAL FUND TO FIGHT AIDS, TUBERCULOSIS

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

provider-org.narrative: GLOBAL FUND TO FIGHT AIDS, TUBERCULOSIS

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
SPI-1: Proportion of pregnant women attending antenatal clinics who received three or more doses of intermittent preventive treatment for malaria
TCP-1(M): Number of notified cases of all forms of TB-(i.e. bacteriologically confirmed + clinically diagnosed), includes new and relapse cases
VC-3(M): Number of long-lasting insecticidal nets distributed to targeted risk groups through continuous distribution
TCP-2(M): Treatment success rate- all forms: Percentage of TB cases, all forms, bacteriologically confirmed plus clinically diagnosed, successfully treated (cured plus treatment completed) among all TB cases registered for treatment during a specified period, new and relapse cases
CM-1a(M): Proportion of suspected malaria cases that receive a parasitological test at public sector health facilities
MDR TB-2(M): Number of TB cases with RR-TB and/or MDR-TB notified
CM-4: Proportion of health facilities without stock-outs of key commodities during the reporting period
CM-2a(M): Proportion of confirmed malaria cases that received first-line antimalarial treatment at public sector health facilities
MDR TB-3(M): Number of cases with RR-TB and/or MDR-TB that began second-line treatment
TCP-4: Percentage of reporting units reporting no stock-outs of anti-TB drugs on the last day of the quarter
TB/HIV-5: Percentage of registered new and relapse TB patients with documented HIV status
TB/HIV-6(M): Percentage of HIV-positive new and relapse TB patients on ART during TB treatment
TCS-1(M): Percentage of people living with HIV currently receiving antiretroviral therapy
PMTCT-2.1: Percentage of HIV-positive pregnant women who received ART during pregnancy
KP-1c(M): Percentage of sex workers reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services
KP-1a(M): Percentage of men who have sex with men reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services
YP-2: Percentage of adolescent girls and young women (AGYW) reached with HIV prevention progra

comment.narrative:
19% of pregnant women attending antenatal clinics received three or more doses of intermittent preventive treatment for malaria (2016). 57,877 notified cases of all forms of TB-(i.e. bacteriologically confirmed + clinically diagnosed), includes new and relapse cases (2017).
175,329 long-lasting insecticidal nets distributed to targeted risk groups (2017)
66.4% of TB cases, all forms, bacteriologically confirmed plus clinically diagnosed, successfully treated among all TB cases registered for treatment (2017)
7,139,430 (92.8%) out of 7,695,594 suspected malaria cases that receive a parasitological test at public sector health facilities (2017)
534 TB cases with RR-TB and/or MDR-TB notified (2017)
1,464 (52,8) out of 2,775 health facilities without stock-outs of key commodities during the reporting period (2017)
1,748 (63%) out of 2,775 health facilities without stock-out of key commodities (ACTs) during the reporting period (2017)
2,874,247 (77.9%) out of 3,691,394 confirmed malaria cases that received first-line antimalarial treatment at public sector health facilities (2017)
534 of cases with RR-TB and/or MDR-TB that began second-line treatment (2017)
32,192.00 (55.6%) out of 57,877 registered new and relapse TB patients with documented HIV status (2017)
1,401.00 (38.8%) out of 3,613 HIV-positive new and relapse TB patients on ART during TB treatment (2017)
77,559 (26.3%) out of 295,452 people living with HIV currently receiving antiretroviral therapy (2017)
7,008 (36.3%) out of 19,315 HIV-positive pregnant women who received ART during pregnancy (2017)

113,820 (20.37%) out of 558,657 pregnant women who attended antenatal clinics, during this period, received three or more doses of intermittent preventive treatment for malaria
29,664 notified cases of all forms of TB-(i.e. bacteriologically confirmed + clinically diagnosed), includes new and relapse cases
335,422 (27%) of the planned 1,235,768 long-lasting insecticidal nets were distributed to targeted risk groups, through continuous distribution
75.71% (19,104 / 25,232) of TB cases, all forms, bacteriologically confirmed plus clinically diagnosed, were successfully treated (cured plus treatment completed) among all TB cases registered for treatment during a specified period, new and relapse cases
7,300,249 (92.24%) out of 7,914,815 of the suspected malaria cases at public sector health facilities, received a parasitological test
443 (47%) out of the 952 TB cases with RR-TB and/or MDR-TB were notified
496 (54.75%) out of the 906 notified health facilities did not have stock-outs of key commodities during the reporting period
706 (77.92%) out of the 906 health facilities did not have stock out of key commodities (ACTs) during the reporting period
3,372,590 (80.40%) out of the 4,194,657 confirmed malaria cases at public sector health facilities, received first-line antimalarial treatment.
188 (28%) out of all 828 cases with RR-TB and/or MDR-TB, began second-line treatment
Of the 18 reporting units 11.11% (2 / 18) reported no stock-outs of anti-TB drugs on the last day of the quarter
2,774 (9.35%) out of the 29,664 new and relapse TB patients registered in the TB register, had documented HIV status
992 (56.52%) out of the 1,755 HIV-positive new and relapse TB patients were on ART during TB treatment
130,005 (38.24%) out of 340,000 people living with HIV currently receiving antiretroviral therapy
9,396 (67.11%) out of 14,000 HIV-positive pregnant women received ART during pregnancy
8,725 (25.15%) out of 34,691 sex workers were reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services
1,154 (13.19%) out of 8,749 MSM were reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services;
41,823 (4.66%) out of 897,772 adolescent girls and young women (AGYW) were reached with HIV prevention programs- defined package of services
16,902.00 (73.59%) out of 12,439 HMIS or other routine reporting units submitted timely reports according to national guidelines
No target to report. Project closed in June 30, 2021. The project is currently following the financial closure process.
